awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  CEDAR:  Comparative Investigation of Kilometer-scale Auroral E and F Region Irregularities with a Global Positioning System (GPS) Scintillation Array
awd_abstract_narration:
Ionospheric irregularities diffract and refract radio waves. These effects present as Global Positioning System (GPS) signal phase and/or amplitude scintillation. The proposed activities consist of analyzing ionospheric irregularities sensed by a GPS scintillation array at the Poker Flat Research Range (PFRR) in Alaska that can resolve horizontal scales as small as 10 km. The Principal Investigators (PIs) will recover properties of the plasma structures such as electron content, drift velocity, and the horizontal dimensions of the irregularities. A primary research goal is to use the spatial structuring information to characterize the E- and F-region turbulence energy cascades. 

These tasks will clarify whether turbulence explains observed GPS scintillations, and enhance understanding of the role of turbulence in magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling. Broader impacts include career development of 2 junior faculty - at least one of them female - and graduate student support. This research is also highly pertinent to the National Space Weather Action Plan. During extreme events, the E- and F-region irregularities that are the focus of this research's science can migrate to lower latitudes and significantly affect communications and navigation systems. Through its support and utilization of GPS, radio and optical data, this research maintains observational capability for space-weather operations.

por.por_cntn:
The world depends heavily on the Global positioning system (GPS) and Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS) for navigation and precision timings. The radio signals from these satellites travel through the ionosphere which is a part of the upper atmosphere filled with charged particles. There are structures in the ionosphere similar to the clouds in the atmosphere which are either less or more dense compared to the background and are very dynamic in nature. They are aligned along the earth's magnetic field lines but may also cross them as horizontally fast-moving flows. The dynamic ionosphere creates disturbances in the radio signals or scintillations (like the twinkling of starlight) and can affect our ability to reliably use these signals. The goal of this project is to study these structures in the ionosphere or irregularities using GPS signals from the SAGA array of GPS receivers installed in Poker Flat Alaska, and using simulations to find out how they behave as a function of the height. There are two heights we looked at 120 km which is the E region and around 350 km which is the peak of the F region.

The specific objectives of this project were to explore the differences in the shapes in the E and F region, different physics causing either the phase or the power of the signal to vary at different heights, and whether the larger structures always break down into smaller structures or smaller structures combine to become the larger structures. 

For this, we used the data from SAGA GPS receivers, data available from other nearby instruments like all-sky imagers and radars, and a forward propagation model called SIGMA which basically simulates how the signal from a satellite travels through space, ionospheric irregularities, and to the ground. Different spectral models of the ionosphere and a configuration space model (which is a statistical model) were employed to recreate the ionosphere. We applied an inverse method (sort of a reverse engineering technique) to understand the irregularity that caused a certain scintillation signal. This method is particularly useful in nature where we cannot control how nature behaves and set up different experiments. It helped us to 'remotely sense' and understand the far-away ionosphere that is potentially causing harm to the GPS signals.

We were able to find out that the structures are like long rods along the Earth's magnetic field in the E region and sheets in the F region. Using simulations we also discovered that the GPS signal we observe on the ground gives us a good idea of how irregularities behave (spectrally -- in frequency domain) at 120 km or 350 km. We also identified how the speed of the irregularities affects the signal we see on the ground. Using different ways of filtering the data and modeling different speeds of the irregularities, we explored the effects of refraction, which is similar to the bending of light, versus diffraction, which is the spreading of the light. We identified several events where we suspect larger-scale structures breaking into smaller ones. These are the events when the amplitude and phase of the signals are following each other. We published some of these results at conferences, in journals, and in a book chapter. 

In terms of STEM activities, this project partially supported an early-career female faculty as the PI and a Ph.D. student for his first 3 years. This Ph.D. student was trained as an independent researcher and is now able to handle the complicated theory of scintillation. PI also closely mentored an external Ph.D. student for his Ph.D. work on scintillations, modeling, and diffraction Vs refraction study. This project partially supported PI's time for the same. At least 4 undergraduate students (including one female student) were funded for the summer and semester projects through this grant. Three of the four students continued to work with the PI for more than 2 years on several different projects, and later secured jobs in some well-known companies owing to their extensive research experience in the PI's lab. One undergraduate student was involved in an eclipse experiment where we borrowed an Embry-Riddle GPS receiver from the PI's lab and temporarily relocated it to Clemson during the great solar eclipse in 2017. We observed a dip in the total electron content which was in agreement with the predicted dip by the Michigan university's ionospheric model. This work was presented by the UG student at the AGU meeting in 2017. It was also a very good field training experience for the then-sophomore UG student who was inspired to continue working in the PI's lab on several different projects for the next 4 years. His work on a separate machine learning project is now being submitted to a journal.
